questions.question: Solution Provider Name
Solution Name
Solution Description
Solution Provider Contact Name
Solution Provider Contact Title
Solution Provider Contact Email
Solution Provider Contact Phone Number
Country of Company Headquarters
Employee Work Locations (all)
questions.reason: Determines where solution provider employees will be physically located.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Do you have a dedicated software and system development team(s) (e.g., customer support, implementation, product management, etc.)?*
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to create a dedicated software and system development team.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the structure and size of your software and system development teams. (e.g., customer support, implementation, product management, etc.).
questions.reason: Understanding the development team size (and capabilities) of a solution provider has a significant impact on their ability to produce and maintain code, adhering to secure coding best practices. The size of a solution provider will determine their use of dedicated development teams, or lack thereof. Use the knowledge of this response when evaluating other solution provider statements.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for solution provider team strategies will be unique to your institution and may depend on the underlying infrastructures needed to support a system for your specific use case.

questions.question: Describe your organization’s business background and ownership structure, including all parent and subsidiary relationships.
questions.standard_guidance: Include circumstances that may involve offshoring or multinational agreements.
questions.no_guidance: Include circumstances that may involve offshoring or multinational agreements.
questions.yes_guidance: Include circumstances that may involve offshoring or multinational agreements.
questions.reason: This information defines the scale of company (support, resources, skillsets), general information about the organization that may be concerning.
questions.followup: Follow-up responses to this one are normally unique to their response. Vague answers here usually result in some footprinting of a solution provider to determine their "reputation."

questions.question: Have you operated without unplanned disruptions to this solution in the past 12 months?
questions.no_guidance: Provide a detailed summary of the unplanned disruption.
questions.reason: We want transparency from the solution provider, and an honest answer to this question, regardless of the response, is a good step in building trust.
questions.followup: If a solution provider says "yes," it is taken at face value. If your organization is capable of conducting reconnaissance, it is encouraged. If a solution provider has experienced a breach, evaluate the circumstances of the incident and what the solution provider has done in response to the breach.

questions.question: Do you have a dedicated information security staff or office?
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to create an information security office for your organization.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe your information security office, including size, talents, resources, etc.
questions.reason: The size and capabilities of a solution provider's security program have a significant impact on its ability to respond effectively to a security incident. The size of a solution provider will determine their security operation size or lack thereof. Use the knowledge of this response when evaluating other solution provider statements.
questions.followup: Vague responses to this question should be investigated further. Solution Providers without dedicated security personnel commonly have no security or security is embedded or dual-homed within operations (administrators). Ask about separation of duties, principle of least privilege, etc. There are many ways to get additional program state information from the solution provider.

questions.question: Use this area to share information about your environment that will assist those who are assessing your company's data security program.
questions.standard_guidance: Share any details that would help information security analysts assess your solution.
questions.no_guidance: Share any details that would help information security analysts assess your solution.
questions.yes_guidance: Share any details that would help information security analysts assess your solution.
questions.reason: For the 20% that HECVAT may not cover, this gives the solution provider a chance to support their other responses. Beware when this area is populated with sales hype or other irrelevant information. Thorough documentation, supporting evidence, and/or robust responses go a long way in building trust in this assessment process.
questions.followup: This is a freebie to help the solution provider state their case. If a solution provider does not add anything here (or it is just sales stuff), we can assume it was filled out by a sales engineer and questions will be evaluated with higher scrutiny.

questions.question: Are you offering a cloud-based product?
questions.standard_guidance: If you are only offering a service, or are offering a product that is not cloud-based, answer "no".
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the Product and Infrastructure worksheets
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the Product and Infrastructure worksheets

questions.question: Does your product or service have an interface?
questions.standard_guidance: This includes any interface for end users and interfaces used by administrators at the institution.
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the IT Accessibility worksheet.
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the IT Accessibility worksheet.

questions.question: Are you providing consulting services?
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the Consulting section in the Case-Specific worksheet
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the Consulting section in the Case-Specific worksheet

questions.question: Does your solution have AI features, or are there plans to implement AI features in the next 12 months?
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the Artificial Intelligence (AI) worksheet
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the Artificial Intelligence (AI) worksheet

questions.question: Does your solution process protected health information (PHI) or any data covered by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)?
questions.standard_guidance: Answer "yes" if your solution handles personal health information (PHI), either directly or via a third party.
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the HIPAA section in the Case-Specific worksheet
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the HIPAA section in the Case-Specific worksheet

questions.question: Is the solution designed to process, store, or transmit credit card information?
questions.standard_guidance: Answer yes if your solution handles PCI (credit card) information, either directly or via a third party.
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the PCI-DSS section in the Case-Specific worksheet
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the PCI-DSS section in the Case-Specific worksheet

questions.question: Does operating your solution require the institution to operate a physical or virtual appliance in their own environment or to provide inbound firewall exceptions to allow your employees to remotely administer systems in the institution's environment?
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the On-Prem section in the Case-Specific worksheet
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the On-Prem section in the Case-Specific worksheet

questions.question: Does your solution have access to personal or institutional data?
questions.standard_guidance: This includes patient data, student data, employment data, human research data, financial data, etc.
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the Privacy tab
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the Privacy tab

questions.question: Do you have a well-documented business continuity plan (BCP), with a clear owner, that is tested annually?*
questions.reason: Testing a business continuity plan is an important action that improves the efficiency and accuracy of a solutiuon provider's continuity plans. Vague responses to this question should be met with concern and appropriate follow-up, based on your institutions risk tolerance.

questions.question: Do you have a well-documented disaster recovery plan (DRP), with a clear owner, that is tested annually?*
questions.reason: Testing a disaster recovery plan is an important action that improves the efficiency and accuracy of a solutiuon provider's recovery plans. Vague responses to this question should be met with concern and appropriate follow-up, based on your institutions risk tolerance.

questions.question: Have you undergone a SSAE 18/SOC 2 audit?
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to undergo a SSAE 18 audit.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide the date of assessment and include a SOC 2 Type 2 (preferred) or SOC 3 report. If you have a SOC 3 report, state how to obtain a copy. Indicate if your hosting provider was the subject of the audit.
questions.reason: SSAE 18 and SOC2 audits are standard documentation, relevant to institutions requiring a solution provider to undergo SSAE 18 audits.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for SSAE 18 content will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Do you conform with a specific industry standard security framework (e.g., NIST Cybersecurity Framework, CIS Controls, ISO 27001, etc.)?
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to conform to an industry standard security framework.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide documentation on how your organization conforms to your chosen framework and indicate current certification levels, where appropriate.
questions.reason: The details of the standard are not the focus here; it is the fact that a solution provider builds their environment around a standard and that they continually evaluate and assess their security programs.
questions.followup: In an ideal world, a solution provider will conform to an industry framework that is adopted by an institution. When this synergy does not exist, the interpretation of the solution provider's responses must be interpreted in the context of the institution's environment. Follow-up inquires for industry frameworks (and levels of adoption) will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Can you provide overall system and/or application architecture diagrams, including a full description of the data flow for all components of the system?
questions.no_guidance: Provide a detailed summary of overall system and/or application architecture.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide your diagrams (or a valid link to it) upon submission.
questions.reason: Managing and protecting institution data is the reason organizations perform security and risk assessments. Privacy policies outline how solution providers will obtain, use, share, and protect institutional data and as such, should be robust in its language. Beware of vaguely worded privacy policies.
questions.followup: Inquire about any privacy language the solution provider may have. It may not be ideal but there may be something available to assess or enough to have your legal counsel or policy/privacy professionals review.

questions.question: Does your organization have a data privacy policy?
questions.no_guidance: Describe your plans to create a data privacy policy.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide your data privacy document (or a valid link to it) upon submission.
questions.reason: Managing and protecting institutional data is the reason organizations perform security and risk assessments. Privacy policies outline how solution providers will obtain, use, share, and protect institutional data and as such, should be robust in its language. Beware of vaguely worded privacy policies.
questions.followup: Inquire about any privacy language the solution provider may have. It may not be ideal but there may be something available to assess or enough to have your legal counsel or policy/privacy professionals review.

questions.question: Do you have a documented, and currently implemented, employee onboarding and offboarding policy?
questions.no_guidance: Briefly summarize your response.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a reference to your employee onboarding and offboarding policy and supporting documentation or submit it along with this fully populated HECVAT.
questions.reason: Managing and protecting a solution provider's assets through appropriate human resource management is of upmost importance. Knowing how roles and access controls are implemented (directed by policy) within a solution provider's infrastructure during the onboarding and offboarding processes is indicative of how access control is regarded in other areas on the provider (solution provider).
questions.followup: Unsatisfactory answers should be met with questions about access control authority, roles and responsibilities (of access grantors), administrative privileges within the solution provider's infrastructure(s), etc.

questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet

questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet

questions.question: Solution Provider Accessibility Contact Email
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet

questions.question: Solution Provider Accessibility Contact Phone Number
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet

questions.question: Web Link to Accessibility Statement or VPAT
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: VPAT can also be added as an attachment
questions.no_guidance: VPAT can also be added as an attachment
questions.yes_guidance: VPAT can also be added as an attachment

questions.question: Has a VPAT or ACR been created or updated for the solution and version under consideration within the past 12 months?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: If your answer is “I do not know,” select “no.” If the VPAT/ACR is for an older version of the product or has not been updated, its information does not accurately reflect the accessibility of the product under consideration and the response should be "no." Provide a link or attachment to the most recent VPAT/ACR.
questions.no_guidance: Please state your plans (when and by whom) to complete a VPAT.
questions.yes_guidance: State the date the VPAT was completed. Include this VPAT in your submission and/or link to its web location.
questions.reason: VPATs (Voluntary Product Accessibility Template) / ACRs (Accessibility Conformance Report, a completed VPAT) are standard accessibility reporting formats from the ITIC <https://www.itic.org/policy/accessibility/vpat>. They can be self-assessments from a solution provider, though higher confidence is given if completed by expert third parties. It is important to confirm the version of the product tested and reported on for the VPAT matches the one under consideration.
questions.followup: Cross-reference Accessibility Conformance Reports (ACR) with any answers from ITAC-14 about product roadmaps for accessibility improvements.

questions.question: Will your company agree to meet your stated accessibility standard or WCAG 2.1 AA as part of your contractual agreement for the solution?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.reason: Federal regulation requires that technology products conform to WCAG 2.1 AA. Technology platforms that do not substantially conform to this standard put schools at risk of not complying with these requirements.

questions.question: Does the solution substantially conform to WCAG 2.1 AA?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: Solutions "substantially conform" if they entirely meet WCAG 2.1 AA or if almost all user and administrator features conform. Documentation about limitations and/or workarounds should be provided where WCAG conformance is not presently achieved. If the solution substantially conforms to a newer standard such as WCAG 2.2 AA, answer "yes."
questions.no_guidance: Solutions "substantially conform" if they entirely meet WCAG 2.1 AA or if almost all user and administrator features conform. Documentation about limitations and/or workarounds should be provided where WCAG conformance is not presently achieved. If the solution substantially conforms to a newer standard such as WCAG 2.2 AA, answer "yes."
questions.yes_guidance: Solutions "substantially conform" if they entirely meet WCAG 2.1 AA or if almost all user and administrator features conform. Documentation about limitations and/or workarounds should be provided where WCAG conformance is not presently achieved. If the solution substantially conforms to a newer standard such as WCAG 2.2 AA, answer "yes."
questions.reason: Federal regulation requires that technology products conform to WCAG 2.1 AA. Technology platforms that do not substantially conform to this standard put schools at risk of not complying with these requirements.

questions.question: Do you have a documented and implemented process for reporting and tracking accessibility issues?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: Reporting and fixing accessibility issues is critical to a mature process. If the process for this question is merely a "feature request" and tracker, the answer to this question should be "no."
questions.no_guidance: State how users should report accessibility issues. Describe any expected related process updates.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the process and any recent examples of fixes as a result of the process.
questions.followup: What is the prioritization of accessibility issues received, and how are they tracked? Is there a regular cadence for tracking and addressing accessibility barriers?

questions.question: Do you have documentation to support the accessibility features of your solution?
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: If specific configurations, settings, themes, author guides, or instructions are needed to ensure accessibility, are instructions on how to do so provided for administrators and end users?
questions.no_guidance: Provide plans for any documentation that would make accessible content, features, and functions easily knowable by end users.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide examples with links where possible.
questions.reason: Has the solution provider documented any additional information needed by users in order to create accessible products with the solution? Are there tutorials, if needed, on how assistive technology users can best use the solution (platforms tested and works best, shortcuts) etc.? In other words, are they taking care of the end users? Accessibility is more than completing checklists.
questions.followup: If claims are made about accessibility and there is no supporting documentation on how they can be achieved, ensure that intended configurations and uses of the product in question were assessed for any accessibility documentation or claims.

questions.question: Has a third-party expert conducted an audit of the most recent version of your solution?
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: Audit results, including VPAT/ACRs, are voluntary reports often generated by the creator of the product. Audits conducted and reports generated by expert third parties give greater confidence to customers.
questions.no_guidance: Please provide plans (when and by whom) of any planned audit, or a rationale if no third-party audit is planned.
questions.yes_guidance: State when the audit was conducted and by whom. Include the results in your submission and/or link to its web location.
questions.reason: Third-party test results lend more credence to accessibility claims in documentation. It is possible that well-qualified first parties may still deliver meaningful results via a VPAT/ACR. Ensuring results for the most recent versions means purchasing decisions are not made with outdated information.

questions.question: Do you have a documented and implemented process for verifying accessibility conformance?
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.no_guidance: Summarize how you ensure accessible solutions. Provide plans to develop documented processes to validate accessibility.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe your processes and methodologies for validating accessibility conformance.
questions.reason: The goal of accessibility is ultimately usability by persons with disabilities. Expert staff and automated testing are important, but automated tools can only detect ~25% of issues so must be supplemented with additional methodologies. Best practice would include testing by people with disabilities. At minimum, some manual testing needs to be conducted in the verification process. The use of overlays or AI plugin solutions to help products "automatically conform" with accessibility guidelines is presently inadequate and should impact scores negatively.

questions.question: Have you adopted a technical or legal standard of conformance for the solution?
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: Various federal and state governments in the United States and around the world have mandated accessibility technical requirements that should be considered and may be required when selling solutions to institutions in these jurisdictions.
questions.no_guidance: Summarize your decision to not adopt a technical or legal standard of conformance for the solution.
questions.yes_guidance: Indicate which primary standards and all additional standards the solution meets.
questions.reason: Knowing the standard solution providers aim for ensures aligned goals. For example, WCAG 2.0 or §508 specify accessibility standards from 2008 that may not meet present needs. WCAG 2.2 is the most current, and 2.1 AA is the most commonly cited current technical accessibility standard.

questions.question: Can you provide a current, detailed accessibility roadmap with delivery timelines?
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: A detailed accessibility roadmap should reference improvements and progress on known accessibility issues as appropriate but does not necessarily need to list unreleased product features.
questions.no_guidance: Please provide any plans to develop and share an accessibility roadmap in the future.
questions.yes_guidance: Comment on how far into the future the roadmap extends. Provide evidence (including links) of having delivered upon the accessibility roadmap in the past.
questions.reason: If solution do not fully conform to accessibility standards, it is important that solution providers have a roadmap specifying how they will work to achieve it. A roadmap with delivery timelines is best supported by evidence of prior delivery on such timelines. Analysts can better predict time to conformance and institutions can plan accordingly.
questions.followup: If no roadmap is available, seek additional information from the solution provider such as release notes that address accessibility and any feedback from users that address the accessibility of the solution.

questions.question: Do you expect your staff to maintain a current skill set in IT accessibility?
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: How do you ensure that your professional staff keeps current with digital accessibility laws and best practices? Is your staff able to evaluate and test this product with assistive technologies such as a screen reader or alternative input devices? Examples of staff certification may include IAAP certifications <https://www.accessibilityassociation.org/s/professional-certifications> or §508 Trusted Tester <https://www.dhs.gov/trusted-tester>.
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to ensure appropriate and ongoing staff knowledge about accessibility.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide any further relevant information about how expertise is maintained; include any accessibility certifications staff may hold (e.g., IAAP WAS <https://www.accessibilityassociation.org/certifications> or DHS Trusted Tester <https://section508.gov/test/trusted-tester>).
questions.reason: Having accessibility expertise within the staff supports the proactive development of accessible solutions. If staff lack sufficient accessibility expertise, then accessibility improvements may only be the result of the solution provider reacting to issues or reports of access barriers submitted by clients of the solution provider.

questions.question: Do you have documented processes and procedures for implementing accessibility into your development lifecycle?
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: Describe where accessibility falls in the development and product lifecycle. Is it at the beginning of your project development or after the product is otherwise complete before launch? Do you incorporate accessibility in your development methods, such as Agile scrums? Does your customer-facing accessibility reporting match your development processes (i.e., Agile methods are best represented using a roadmap and timeline; revised VPAT/ACRs provide a snapshot in time of a given release)?
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to update processes and procedures to better incorporate accessibility.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide further details in Additional Information.
questions.reason: This question is designed to understand how accessibility is included in new versions and features of solutions, particularly with solution providers that implement Agile or similar methodologies where software is updated frequently and continuously.

questions.question: Can all functions of the application or service be performed using only the keyboard?
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.no_guidance: Indicate a plan to test the solution; develop a roadmap for keyboard accessibility or any further context.
questions.yes_guidance: State when and on which platform this was verified.
questions.reason: One critical accessibility requirement is the full use of a product using only the keyboard, -no mouse or trackpad. This requirement is easy for a nontechnical or non-accessibility expert to understand and verify.
questions.followup: To confirm keyboard-only claims, follow the how-to at Minimum Expectations for applications webpage <https://go.iu.edu/minimum-expectations> from Indiana University or reference WebAIM’s Keyboard Testing guidance <https://webaim.org/techniques/keyboard/#testing>.

questions.question: Does your product rely on activating a special "accessibility mode," a "lite version," or using an alternate interface (including “overlay” or AI-based alternates)  for accessibility purposes?
questions.if_then: If REQU-02 is no, populate solution provider answer with cell b3 in Auto Responses worksheet
questions.standard_guidance: Third-party overlays or add-ons are not sufficient for products to conform with accessibility standards. If there is an accessibility mode, does it address a specific accessibility need? Are plans in place to remove the accessible version, and are these distinctions delineated on your roadmap and timeline?
questions.no_guidance: Third-party overlays or add-ons are not sufficient for products to conform with accessibility standards. If there is an accessibility mode, does it address a specific accessibility need? Are plans in place to remove the accessible version, and are these distinctions delineated on your roadmap and timeline?
questions.yes_guidance: Describe any feature differences between standard and accessible modes, along with any timelines or plans to merge products into a universally designed platform.
questions.reason: Third-party overlays or add-ons are not sufficient for products to conform with accessibility Standards (more information at <https://overlayfactsheet.com>). Lite or alternate versions for accessibility versions are typically not feature equivalent and are less maintained. Plans should be shared on how a provider intends to bridge such a gap and work toward accessibility on the primary product path.

questions.question: Do you perform security assessments of third-party companies with which you share data (e.g., hosting providers, cloud services, PaaS, IaaS, SaaS)?*
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to perform security assessments of third-party companies.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a summary of your practices that assures that the third party will be subject to the appropriate standards regarding security, service recoverability, and confidentiality.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: In the context of the CIA triad, this question is focused on system integrity, ensuring that system changes are only executed by authorized users. Additionally, it is expected that devices (for administrators, solution provider staff, and affiliates) that are used to access the solution provider's systems are properly managed and secured.
questions.followup: Follow up with a robust question set if the solution provider cannot clearly state full control of the integrity of their system(s). Questions about administrator access on end-user devices and other maintenance and patching type questions are appropriate.

questions.question: Do you have contractual language in place with third parties governing access to institutional data?*
questions.standard_guidance: List each third party and why institutional data is shared with them. Format example: [Third Party Name] - Reason
questions.no_guidance: List each third party and why institutional data is shared with them. Format example: [Third Party Name] - Reason
questions.yes_guidance: List each third party and why institutional data is shared with them. Format example: [Third Party Name] - Reason
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: The sharing of institutional data to fourth-parties may increase the risk to the institutation and thus, we want to know who gets what data, when they get that data, and why they get that data.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries concerning third-party data sharing will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Do the contracts in place with these third parties address liability in the event of a data breach?*
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: Knowing the protections and legal agreements in place for third-party data sharing may assist analysts in determininng residual risk.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries concerning legal agreements with third parties will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Do you have an implemented third-party management strategy?*
questions.standard_guidance: Robust answers from the solution provider improve the quality and efficiency of the security assessment process.
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to implement a third-party management strategy.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide additional information that may help analysts better understand your environment and how it relates to third-party solutions.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: Every organization needs to actively understand and manage its supply chain. The solution provider's understanding of who their third-party partners are and their ability to manage those relationships effectively and consistently speaks to the amount of risk your institution is taking on by contracting with them. Modern technologies allow for rapid deployment of features and with them come changes to an established code environment. The focus of this question is to verify a solution provider's practice of regression testing their code and verifying that previously nonexistent risks are not introduced into a known, secured environment.
questions.followup: If "No," inquire if there are plans to implement these processes. Ask the solution provider to summarize their decision behind not scanning their assets for vulnerabilities. Be sure that the solution provider answers for both systems AND applications. Do not let good practices in one overshadow deficiencies in the other.

questions.question: Do you have a process and implemented procedures for managing your hardware supply chain (e.g., telecommunications equipment, export licensing, computing devices)?
questions.standard_guidance: Make sure you address any national or regional regulations.
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to create a process and implemented procedures for managing your hardware supply chain.
questions.yes_guidance: State what countries and/or regions this process is compliant with.
questions.reason: Understanding a solution provider's hardware supply chain can reveal infrastructure risks that may not be apparent by other means. In some cases, the use of trusted components may be favorable. In others, it may initiate the assessment of the solution provider's environment in more detail and/or expand the scope of the institution's assessment.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries concerning hardware supply chain will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Will the consultant require access to the institution's network resources?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-03 is no, populate solution provider answer with b4 in Auto Responses tab
questions.reason: Consultants are often used to implement, maintain, fix, and assess technology environments. In these cases, third-party consultants have access to institutional data, and appropriate access, whether remote or onsite, must be protected during the consulting engagement.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Has the consultant received training on (sensitive, HIPAA, PCI, etc.) data handling?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-03 is no, populate solution provider answer with b4 in Auto Responses tab
questions.reason: Consultants are often used to implement, maintain, fix, and assess technology environments. In these cases, third-party consultants have access to institutional data, and appropriate access, whether remote or onsite, must be protected during the consulting engagement.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Is the data encrypted (at rest) while in the consultant's possession?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-03 is no, populate solution provider answer with b4 in Auto Responses tab
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: Consultants are often used to implement, maintain, fix, and assess technology environments. In these cases, third-party consultants have access to institutional data, and appropriate access, whether remote or onsite, must be protected during the consulting engagement.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Can access be restricted based on source IP address?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-03 is no, populate solution provider answer with b4 in Auto Responses tab
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: Consultants are often used to implement, maintain, fix, and assess technology environments. In these cases, third-party consultants have access to institutional data, and appropriate access, whether remote or onsite, must be protected during the consulting engagement.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Will the consulting take place on-premises?
questions.if_then: If REQU-03 is no, populate solution provider answer with b4 in Auto Responses tab
questions.reason: Consultants are often used to implement, maintain, fix, and assess technology environments. In these cases, third-party consultants have access to institutional data, and appropriate access, whether remote or onsite, must be protected during the consulting engagement.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Will the consultant require access to hardware in the institution's data centers?
questions.if_then: If REQU-03 is no, populate solution provider answer with b4 in Auto Responses tab
questions.reason: Consultants are often used to implement, maintain, fix, and assess technology environments. In these cases, third-party consultants have access to institutional data, and appropriate access, whether remote or onsite, must be protected during the consulting engagement.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Will the consultant require an account within the institution's domain (@*.edu)?
questions.if_then: If REQU-03 is no, populate solution provider answer with b4 in Auto Responses tab
questions.reason: Consultants are often used to implement, maintain, fix, and assess technology environments. In these cases, third-party consultants have access to institutional data, and appropriate access, whether remote or onsite, must be protected during the consulting engagement.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Will any data be transferred to the consultant's possession?
questions.if_then: If REQU-03 is no, populate solution provider answer with b4 in Auto Responses tab
questions.reason: Consultants are often used to implement, maintain, fix, and assess technology environments. In these cases, third-party consultants have access to institutional data, and appropriate access, whether remote or onsite, must be protected during the consulting engagement.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Will the consultant need remote access to the institution's network or systems?
questions.if_then: If REQU-03 is no, populate solution provider answer with b4 in Auto Responses tab
questions.reason: Consultants are often used to implement, maintain, fix, and assess technology environments. In these cases, third-party consultants have access to institutional data, and appropriate access, whether remote or onsite, must be protected during the consulting engagement.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Are access controls for institutional accounts based on structured rules, such as role-based access control (RBAC), attribute-based access control (ABAC), or policy-based access control (PBAC)?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: This includes end users, administrators, service accounts, etc. PBAC would include various dynamic controls such as conditional access, risk-based access, location-based access, or system activity–based access.
questions.no_guidance: Describe any limitations that prevent support for RBAC for Institutional accounts.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe available roles.
questions.reason: Understanding access control capabilities allows an institution to estimate the type of maintenance efforts will be involved to manage a system. Depending on the users, concerns may or not be elevated. The value of this question is largely determined by the deployment strategy and use case of the solution under review. This question is specific to end users.
questions.followup: Ask the solution provider to summarize the best practices to restrict/control the access given to the institution's end users without the use of RBAC. Make sure to understand the administrative requirements/overhead introduced in the solution provider's environment.

questions.question: Are you using a web application firewall (WAF)?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe compensating controls that protect your web application, if applicable.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the currently implemented WAF.
questions.reason: The use case, solution provider infrastructure, and types of services offered will greatly affect the need for various firewalling devices. The focus of this question is integrity, ensuring that the systems hosting institutional data are limited in need-only communications. The use of a WAF is important in systems in which a solution provider has limited access to the code infrastructure.
questions.followup: If a solution provider states that they outsource their code development and do not run a WAF, there is elevated reason for concern. Verify how code is tested, monitored, and controlled in production environments.

questions.question: Are only currently supported operating system(s), software, and libraries leveraged by the system(s)/application(s) that will have access to institution's data?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: If the web application only works with a subset of modern supported browsers, please indicate that here.
questions.no_guidance: State your plan to migrate to supported operating systems, libraries, and software.
questions.yes_guidance: Please provide a list of all required dependencies.
questions.reason: Solution Provider responses to this question provide clarity on environment constraints that may exist and/or influence future development, configurations, infrastructure, etc. Although the solution provider response may not directly affect end users, the risks of the underlying infrastructure are better understood.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for operating systems leveraged by the solution provider will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Does your application require access to location or GPS data?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Please indicate any future plans that would require access to this data
questions.yes_guidance: Please describe the reasons why in detail and state if that access can be limited to while your app is running.
questions.reason: Sharing location data significantly increases risk factors for users. It's important to understand if this is required.
questions.followup: Ask the solution provider about the need for this requirement, and understand any mitigation strategies that may be possible.

questions.question: Does your application provide separation of duties between security administration, system administration, and standard user functions?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: State plans to implement functionality to provide separation of duties between security administration and system administration functions.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe or provide a reference to the facilities available in the system to provide separation of duties between security administration and system administration functions.
questions.reason: Managing a solution may rely on various teams to administrate a system. In this question, it is security operations and systems administration. This question is focused on how system(s) administration, and the segregation of duties, are implemented in the solution provider's organization, so that system administrators do not also have security responsibilities (e.g., monitoring, mitigating, reporting, etc.).
questions.followup: Ask the solution provider to summarize their best practices for securing their system(s) administratively without the use of RBAC. Make sure to understand the administrative requirements/overhead introduced in the solution provider's environment.

questions.question: Do you subject your code to static code analysis and/or static application security testing prior to release?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to implement static code testing practices into your environment.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a list of all tools utilized during static code analysis or static application security testing.
questions.reason: Code analysis (prior to implementation) can decrease the number of vulnerabilities within a system. Depending on the insight a solution provider has into their code, code testing should be expected. When a solution provider outsources their coding efforts, the use of a web application firewall may be appropriate. In this case, reference the solution provider's response to their use of a WAF.
questions.followup: Ask the solution provider what types of tools they use in testing and who performs the testing of the code. Are developers the ones running the security tests? If static code analysis and/or static application security testing is not conducted, point the solution provider to OWASP's Testing Guide <https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Testing_Guide_v4_Table_of_Contents>.

questions.question: Do you have software testing processes (dynamic or static) that are established and followed?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to implement software testing processes into your environment.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe testing processes, including but not limited to, development of test plans, personnel involved in the testing process, and authorized individual accountable for approval and certification of test results.
questions.reason: Code analysis (prior to implementation) can decrease the number of vulnerabilities within a system. Depending on the insight a solution provider has into their code, code testing should be expected.
questions.followup: If software testing processes are not established and followed, point the solution provider to OWASP's Testing Guide <https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Testing_Guide_v4_Table_of_Contents>.

questions.question: Are access controls for staff within your organization based on structured rules, such as RBAC, ABAC, or PBAC?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: This includes system administrators and third-party personnel with access to the system. PBAC would include various dynamic controls such as conditional access, risk-based access, location-based access, or system activity–based access.
questions.no_guidance: Describe any limitations that prevent support for RBAC within your organization.
questions.yes_guidance: This includes system administrators and third-party personnel with access to the system. PBAC would include various dynamic controls such as conditional access, risk-based access, location-based access, or system activity–based access.
questions.reason: Managing a solution may rely on various professionals to administer a system. This question is focused on how administration, and the segregation of functions, is implemented within the solution provider's infrastructure.
questions.followup: Managing a complex infrastructure requires diligence in protecting access and authority. Unsatisfactory responses may indicate the lack of maturity with a solution provider and/or a flat infrastructure with few individuals with broad authority. Inquire about separation of duties and look for areas of inappropriate functional overlap.

questions.question: Does the system provide data input validation and error messages?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: State plans to implement data input validation and error messaging across all components of your system.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe how your system(s) provide data input validation and error messages.
questions.reason: Input validation is a secure coding best practice, so confirming its implementation is normally a high priority. Error messages (to the system and user) can be used to detect abnormal use and to better protect institutional data. Depending on the criticality of data and the flow of said data, an institution's risk tolerance will be unique to their environment.
questions.followup: Inquire about any planned improvements to these capabilities. Ask about their product roadmap, and try to understand how they prioritize security concerns in their environment.

questions.question: Do you have a process and implemented procedures for managing your software supply chain (e.g., libraries, repositories, frameworks, etc.)
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Include any in-house developed or contract development.
questions.no_guidance: Briefly summarize your response.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide supporting documentation of your processes.
questions.reason: Understanding system requirements and/or dependencies (e.g., libraries, repositories, frameworks, toolkits, modules, etc.) can reveal infrastructure risks that may not be apparent by other means. In some cases, the use of trusted components may be favorable. In others, it may initiate the assessment of the solution provider's environment in more detail and/or expand the scope of the institution's assessment.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries concerning software supply chain will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Have your developers been trained in secure coding techniques?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: State plans to implement a training program on industry standard secure coding practices.
questions.yes_guidance: Summarize your secure coding training.
questions.reason: The adherence to secure coding best practices better positions a solution provider to maintain the CIA triad. Use the knowledge of this response when evaluating other solution provider statements, particularly those focused on development and the protection of communications.
questions.followup: If information security principles are not designed into the product lifecycle, point the solution provider to OWASP's Secure Coding Practices - Quick Reference Guide <https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Secure_Coding_Practices_-_Quick_Reference_Guide>.

questions.question: Was your application developed using secure coding techniques?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: State plans to update your application to adhere to industry secure coding practices.
questions.yes_guidance: Summarize your secure coding practices.
questions.reason: The adherence to secure coding best practices better positions a solution provider to maintain the CIA triad. Use the knowledge of this response when evaluating other solution provider statements, particularly those focused on development and the protection of communications.
questions.followup: If information security principles are not designed into the product lifecycle, point the solution provider to OWASP's Secure Coding Practices - Quick Reference Guide <https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Secure_Coding_Practices_-_Quick_Reference_Guide>.

questions.question: If mobile, is the application available from a trusted source (e.g., App Store, Google Play Store)?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Select N/A if there is no mobile version of your app.
questions.no_guidance: Decribe how the application is distributed. Also, state any plans to publish the app to a trusted source.
questions.yes_guidance: State the application title as listed within the trusted source.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: Distributing application via known, moderately vetted application platform decreases the chances of malicious code distribution. Stand-alone deployments (nontrusted sources) should be looked at more closely.
questions.followup: Ask the solution provider why this deployment strategy is used. Ask if it is a restriction of the app store platform or some other environment restriction.

questions.question: Do you have a fully implemented policy or procedure that details how your employees obtain administrator access to institutional instance of the application?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: State plans to fully implement policy or procedure that details how administrator access is handled in your environment.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe or provide a reference that details how administrator access is handled (e.g., provisioning, principle of least privilege, deprovisioning, etc.).
questions.reason: Protecting administrative accounts is crucial to maintaining system integrity in any environment. This question is targeting privilege creep and unmanaged privileged acccounts to determine if the solution provider properly manages access control in their application/system environments.
questions.followup: Ask the solution provider to summarize their implemented policies and/or procedures

questions.question: Does your solution support single sign-on (SSO) protocols for user and administrator authentication?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Answer "yes" only if user AND administrator authentication is supported. If partially supported, answer "no." Ensure you respond to any guidance in the Additional Information column.
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to support strong authentication practices.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe how strong authentication is enforced (e.g., complex passwords, multifactor tokens, certificates, biometrics, aging requirements, re-use policy).
questions.reason: This question is to set account management expectations for the institution. A system that can integrate with existing, vetted solutions has its advantages and may have less administrative overhead. Also, adherence to standards here gives credit to other standards-oriented questions/responses.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for IAM requirements will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: For customers not using SSO, does your solution support local authentication protocols for user and administrator authentication?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to support local authentication modes.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a detailed description of your local authentication mode practices.
questions.reason: The purpose of this question is understand the solution provider's authentication infrastructure so that additional questions can be formulated for the institution's use case. If you will be using SSO, consider marking this question as "Do Not Score" in column J of the evaluation tab.
questions.followup: The content of this response may or may not have value for the type of use case on the institution. Follow-up inquiries for authentication modes will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: For customers not using SSO, can you enforce password/passphrase complexity requirements (provided by the institution)?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to support password/passphrase complexity requirements.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe how password/passphrase complexity requirements are implemented in the product.
questions.reason: Many institutions have a policy focused on passwords/passphrases, and this question confirms the capacity of a solution provider's solution to comply. If you will be using SSO, consider marking this question as "Do Not Score" in column J of the evaluation tab.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for password/passphrase complexity requirements will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: For customers not using SSO, does the system have password complexity or length limitations and/or restrictions?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Answer "yes" if your solution has internal limits to password complexity (max langth, certain special characters unsupported, etc.).
questions.yes_guidance: Describe these limitations and/or restrictions and state what lengths and complexities are supported.
questions.reason: Many institutions have a policy focused on passwords/passphrases, and this question confirms the capacity of a solution provider's solution to comply. If you will be using SSO, consider marking this question as "Do Not Score" in column J of the evaluation tab.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for password/passphrase limitations and/or restrictions will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: For customers not using SSO, do you have documented password/passphrase reset procedures that are currently implemented in the system and/or customer support?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe your plans to document system password/passphrase reset procedures.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe your documented password/passphrase reset procedures that are currently implemented in the system and/or customer support.
questions.reason: Account management can be a time-consuming part of an information system. Account reset capabilities, built into a system, can reduce burden on institutional support services. If you will be using SSO, consider marking this question as "Do Not Score" in column J of the evaluation tab.
questions.followup: Ask the solution provider how end users will be supported. Ask for training documentation or knowledgebase content. Confirm solution provider and institution responsibilities in this support area (and others).

questions.question: Does your organization participate in InCommon or another eduGAIN-affiliated trust federation?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to participate in InCommon or another eduGAIN-affiliated trust federation.
questions.yes_guidance: List the entity IDs registered in the Additional Information column.
questions.reason: This question defines the solution provider's scope of federated identity practices and their willingness to embrace higher education requirements.
questions.followup: If a solution provider indicates that a system is stand-alone and cannot integrate with community standards, follow up with maturity questions and ask about other commodity type functions or other system requirements your institution may have.

questions.question: Are there any passwords/passphrases hard-coded into your systems or solutions?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a detailed description of passwords/passphrases hard-coded into your systems or solutions.
questions.reason: The response to this question can reveal the use (or not) of coding best practices. If passwords/passphrases are hard-coded into systems/productions, the solution provider should provide robust details supporting why this is required.
questions.followup: Vague responses to this question should be met with concern. Repeat the question if the first answer is insufficient. Ask pointedly to ensure the solution provider is not misunderstanding.

questions.question: Are you storing any passwords in plaintext?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a detailed description stating why account passwords/passphrases are not encrypted in storage.
questions.reason: The focus of this question is confidentiality. It is a straightforward question confirming the encryption of user authentication details.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for password/passphrase encrypted storage will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Are audit logs available that include AT LEAST all of the following: login, logout, actions performed, and source IP address?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to enable audit logs for these data elements.
questions.reason: Strong logging capabilities are vital to the proper management of a system. Implementing an immature system that lacks sufficient logging capabilities exposes an institution to great risk. Depending on your risk tolerance and the use case, your institution may or may not be concerned. The focus of this question is end-user logs.
questions.followup: If a weak response is given, it is appropriate to ask directed questions to get specific information. Ensure that questions are targeted to ensure responses will come from the appropriate party within the solution provider.

questions.question: Describe or provide a reference to the (a) system capability to log security/authorization changes, as well as user and administrator security events (i.e., physical or electronic), such as login failures, access denied, changes accepted; and (b) all requirements necessary to implement logging and monitoring on the system. Include (c) information about SIEM/log collector usage.*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Ensure that all elements of AAAI-10 are clearly stated in your response.
questions.no_guidance: Ensure that all elements of AAAI-10 are clearly stated in your response.
questions.yes_guidance: Ensure that all elements of AAAI-10 are clearly stated in your response.
questions.reason: Strong logging capabilities are vital to the proper management of a system. Implementing an immature system that lacks sufficient logging capabilities exposes an institution to great risk. Depending on your risk tolerance and the use case, your institution may or may not be concerned. The focus of this question is system-related logs (including but not limited to events, state changes, control modification, etc.).
questions.followup: If a weak response is given, it is appropriate to ask directed questions to get specific information. Ensure that questions are targeted to ensure responses will come from the appropriate party within the solution provider.

questions.question: Can you provide the institution documentation regarding the retention period for those logs, how logs are protected, and whether they are accessible to the customer (and if so, how)?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Ensure that all elements of AAAI-11 are clearly stated in your response.
questions.no_guidance: Ensure that all elements of AAAI-11 are clearly stated in your response.
questions.yes_guidance: Ensure that all elements of AAAI-11 are clearly stated in your response.
questions.reason: There are multiple components of this question. When assessing, ensure that the solution provider responds to them all. Logs that are not properly managed may not be available when needed. The purpose of this question is to ensure that the solution provider has a proper security mindset to ensure proper monitoring practices.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for logging details will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: For customers not using SSO, does your application support integration with other authentication and authorization systems?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to support integration with other authentication and authorization systems.
questions.yes_guidance: List which systems and versions supported (such as Active Directory, Kerberos, or other LDAP compatible directory) in Additional Info.
questions.reason: This question is to set account management expectations for the institution. A system that can integrate with existing, vetted solutions has its advantages and may have less administrative overhead. Also, adherence to standards here gives credit to other standards-oriented questions/responses. If you will be using SSO, consider marking this question as "Do Not Score" in column J of the evaluation tab.
questions.followup: If a solution provider indicates that a system is stand-alone and cannot integrate with the institution's infrastructure, follow up with maturity questions and ask about other commodity type functions or other system requirements your institution may have.

questions.question: Do you allow the customer to specify attribute mappings for any needed information beyond a user identifier? (e.g., Reference eduPerson, ePPA/ePPN/ePE)
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to allow customers to specify attribute mappings.
questions.reason: This questions allows an institution to know solution provider system limitations and to help them gauge the resources (that may be needed to implement) required to successfully integrate the solution with institution systems.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for attribute mapping requirements will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: For customers not using SSO, does your application support directory integration for user accounts?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to support external authentication services in place of local authentication.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe all authentication services supported by the system.
questions.reason: System (technical and security) administration is complex, and it is important to understand a system's capabilities to integrate with existing security and access systems. Having to maintain additional accounts increases overhead and may impact your institution's risk footprint. If you will be using SSO, consider marking this question as "Do Not Score" in column J of the evaluation tab.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for system authentication will be unique to your institution (e.g., policy, infrastructure, etc.).

questions.question: Does your solution support any of the following web SSO standards: SAML2 (with redirect flow), OIDC, CAS, or other?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: An answer of "yes" should be well-supported in the Additional Information column, and all elements of interest should be sufficiently addressed.
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to support web SSO in your solution.
questions.yes_guidance: State the web SSO standards supported by your solution and provide additional details about your support, including framework(s) in use, how information is exchanged securely, etc.
questions.reason: This question is to set account management expectations for the institution. A system that can integrate with existing, vetted solutions has its advantages and may have less administrative overhead. Also, adherence to standards here gives credit to other standards-oriented questions/responses.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for IAM requirements will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Do you support differentiation between email address and user identifier?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to support differentiation between email address and user identifier.
questions.reason: This questions allows an institution to know solution provider system limitations and to help them gauge the resources (that may be needed to implement) required to successfully integrate the solution with institution systems.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for identifier requirements will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: For customers not using SSO, does your application and/or user frontend/portal support multifactor authentication (e.g., Duo, Google Authenticator, OTP, etc.)?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to support multifactor authentication in your application.
questions.yes_guidance: List all supported multifactor authentication methods, technologies, and/or solutions and provide a brief summary of each.
questions.reason: 2FA/MFA, implemented correctly, strengthens the security state of a system. 2FA/MFA is commonly implemented and in many use cases is a requirement for account protection purposes. If you will be using SSO, consider marking this question as "Do Not Score" in column J of the evaluation tab.
questions.followup: Ask the solution provider about hardware and software options, future roadmap for implementations and support, etc.

questions.question: Does your application automatically lock the session or log out an account after a period of inactivity?
questions.if_then: If REQU-01 is no, populate solution provider answer with B2 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to support automatic lock or log-out.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the default behavior of this capability.
questions.reason: This is a question to ensure account integrity and institutional data confidentiality.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for inactivity protections will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Will the institution be notified of major changes to your environment that could impact the institution's security posture?*
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to establish a notification mechanism for major environmental changes.
questions.yes_guidance: State how and when the institution will be notified of major changes to your environment.
questions.reason: Notification expectations should be set earlier in the contract/assessment process. Timelines, correspondence medium, and playbook details are all aspects to keep in mind when assessing this response.
questions.followup: If the solution provider's response does not cover the details outlined in the reasoning, follow up and get specific responses for each, as needed.

questions.question: Does the system support client customizations from one release to another?*
questions.standard_guidance: Ensure that all relevant details pertaining to CHNG-06 are clearly stated in your response.
questions.no_guidance: Clarify the lack of support strategy for client customizations from one release to another.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe or provide reference to your solution support strategy in regard to maintaining client customizations from one release to another.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: The solution provider's solution characteristics and the institution's use case will determine the relevancy of this question. The purpose of this question is to understand the underlying infrastructure and how it is maintained across all customers.
questions.followup: In cases where the solution is customized for customer use cases, ensure the solution provider's response covers all aspects of code migration, including backups, data conversions, local resources from the institution, etc., as it relates to code upgrades and/or version adoptions.

questions.question: Do you have an implemented system configuration management process (e.g.,secure "gold" images, etc.)?*
questions.no_guidance: Describe how system configuration management is currently handled in your environment.
questions.yes_guidance: Summarize your implemented system configuration management precess.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: Hardware lifecycles and continuous software updates creates an always-changing landscape in information technology. The focus of this question is the integrity of a solution provider's infrastructure. Mismanagement of system configurations can lead to breakdowns in layers of security.
questions.followup: Solution Providers should have robust documentation when it comes to configuration management. Vague answers to this question should be met with concern. Inquire about the device management tools in use, system lifecycles, complexity of systems, etc., and evaluate the response in the context of company capabilities (see Company Background section).

questions.question: Do you have a documented change management process?
questions.no_guidance: Briefly summarize your response.
questions.yes_guidance: Summarize your current change management process.
questions.reason: The lack of a change management function is indicative of immature program processes. Answers to this question can provide insight into how well their responses (on the HECVAT) represent their actual environment(s).
questions.followup: If a weak response is given to this answer, response scrutiny should be increased. Questions about configuration management, system authority, and documentation are appropriate.

questions.question: Does your change management process minimally include authorization, impact analysis, testing, and validation before moving changes to production?
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to implement change management in your environment or clarify what your change management processes do include.
questions.yes_guidance: Indicate all procedures that are implemented in your change management process. (a) An impact analysis of the upgrade is performed. (b) The change is appropriately authorized. (c) Changes are made first in a test environment. (d) The ability to implement the upgrades/changes in the production environment is limited to appropriate IT personnel.
questions.reason: This question outlines a mature change management process. Changes should be analyzed for impact, officially approved, tested, and performed by authorized users.
questions.followup: If the solution provider's response does not cover the details outlined in the reasoning, follow up and get specific responses, as needed.

questions.question: Does your change management process verify that all required third-party libraries and dependencies are still supported with each major change?
questions.no_guidance: Please describe any plans to implement third-party library dependancy tracking.
questions.yes_guidance: Please describe your program to track these dependancies.
questions.reason: This question is fundamentally about supply chain. The solution provider should be able to document its procedures around tracking libraries maintained by third parties.
questions.followup: If the solution provider's response does not cover the details outlined in the reasoning, follow-up and get specific responses for each, as needed.

questions.question: Do you have policy and procedure, currently implemented, managing how critical patches are applied to all systems and applications?
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to implement policy and procedure(s) to manage how critical patches are applied to systems and applications.
questions.yes_guidance: Summarize the policy and procedure(s) managing how critical patches are applied to systems and applications.
questions.reason: Answers to this question will reveal the solution provider’s knowledge of their IT assets and their ability to respond to notifications about their systems and software.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for the solution provider’s patching practices will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Have you implemented policies and procedures that guide how security risks are mitigated until patches can be applied?
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to implement policy and procedure(s) guiding risk mitigation practices before critical patches can be applied.
questions.yes_guidance: Summarize the policy and procedure(s) guiding risk mitigation practices before critical patches can be applied.
questions.reason: New vulnerabilities are published every day, and solution providers have a responsibility to maintain their software(s). The fundamental nature of operation will expose some risks to the system, but it is crucial that a solution provider recognize its responsibilities and have a plan to implement them, when this time arrives.
questions.followup: Follow-up inquiries for the solution providers patching practices will be institution/implementation specific.

questions.question: Do clients have the option to not participate in or postpone an upgrade to a new release?
questions.no_guidance: Summarize why clients do not have alternative release options.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide reference the the process/procedure to manage releases.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: Unplanned and/or unexpected changes in a complex environment can introduce intolerable risks to the institution. Based on the operating environment of the institution, it may be necessary to postpone (or properly plan) the change to a system. The solution provider's response should clarify their use of a "one code base" method or the ability to run multiple versions concurrently.
