questions.no_guidance: Include the number of years and in what capacity.
questions.yes_guidance: Include the number of years and in what capacity.
questions.reason: We want to establish longevity of a solution and whether or not a solution provider is new to the higher education space.
questions.followup: Normally a solution provider will state their overall longevity but not talk about the software/service/product under evaluation. Follow-ups includes specific questions about the origins of the software/service/product and references will be requested.

questions.question: Do you have existing higher education customers?
questions.if_then: If REQU-07 is no, populate solution provider answer with B8 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: State your primary industry.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a list of higher education references, with contact information.
questions.reason: Higher education is a unique vertical. A solution provider's response to this question can help an analyst set the context for all solution provider responses. Established and/or mature solutions are more likely to have current higher education customers, and therefore understand the environment that we operate in.
questions.followup: A simple "yes" without any references or supporting information should be questioned. Question the size of institutions that are using the solution and the scope of their implementations.

questions.question: Does your solution process FERPA-related data?
questions.standard_guidance: FERPA-related data includes any data maintained by (or on behalf of) the institution that is directly related to an identifiable student.
questions.no_guidance: FERPA-related data includes any data maintained by (or on behalf of) the institution that is directly related to an identifiable student.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide documentation on the types of FERPA data you process and for what purpose, including data unrelated to service delivery such as marketing.
questions.reason: This question will help the institution gain an understanding of the types of data processed by this product or service.
questions.followup: Will data be re-disclosed and/or used for any purpose other than directly providing the service, including quality assurance or marketing?

questions.question: Does your solution process GDPR-related or PIPL-related data?
questions.standard_guidance:
GDPR data includes any data related to an identified or identifiable natural person physically located in the European Economic Area (EEA).
PIPL-related data includes any personal data related to an identified or identifiable person located in the People's Republic of China (PRC)
questions.no_guidance:
GDPR data includes any data related to an identified or identifiable natural person physically located in the European Economic Area (EEA).
PIPL-related data includes any personal data related to an identified or identifiable person located in the People's Republic of China (PRC)
questions.yes_guidance: Provide documentation of any processes or policies that address compliance with GDPR and/or PIPL as appropriate.
questions.reason: This question will help the institution gain an understanding of the types of data processed by this product or service.

questions.question: Does your solution process personal data regulated by state law(s) (e.g., CCPA)?
questions.yes_guidance: Provide documentation of any processes or policies that address compliance with applicable state laws.
questions.reason: This question will help the institution gain an understanding of the types of data processed by this product or service.

questions.question: Does your solution process user-provided data that may contain regulated information?
questions.yes_guidance: Identify any applicable regulations and provide documentation of any processes or policies that address compliance with each.
questions.reason: This question will help the institution gain an understanding of the types of data processed by this product or service.

questions.question: Web Link to Product/Service Privacy Notice
questions.standard_guidance: If multiple notices are implicated, provide all that apply. If any other documents are incorporated by reference, provide them as well.
questions.no_guidance: If multiple notices are implicated, provide all that apply. If any other documents are incorporated by reference, provide them as well.
questions.yes_guidance: If multiple notices are implicated, provide all that apply. If any other documents are incorporated by reference, provide them as well.
questions.reason: To ensure transparency and verify the vendor provides accessible privacy documentation that institutions can review and share with stakeholders.
questions.followup: Please provide the direct URL to your privacy policy and confirm how frequently it is reviewed and updated.

questions.question: Have you had a personal data breach in the past three years that involved reporting to a governmental agency, notice to individuals (including voluntary notice), or notice to another organization or institution?*
questions.yes_guidance: Please provide details as to the nature of the breach and the remediation conducted.
questions.reason: Having a previous data breach can indicate a level of risk that will indicate that the instituion should further investigate changes made after the breach.

questions.question: Use this area to share information about your privacy practices that will assist those who are assessing your company data privacy program.*
questions.standard_guidance: Share any additional details that would help data privacy analysts assess your solution.
questions.no_guidance: Share any additional details that would help data privacy analysts assess your solution.
questions.yes_guidance: Share any additional details that would help data privacy analysts assess your solution.
questions.reason: To gather voluntary disclosures that provide additional context beyond required responses, helping assessors understand the vendor's privacy culture and proactive commitment to data protection.

questions.question: Have you had any violations of your internal privacy policies or violations of applicable privacy law in the past 36 months?
questions.yes_guidance: Provide documentation about the nature of the violation(s) and any remediative action taken.
questions.reason: This question solicits information about internal privacy policy violations and/or violations of applicable privacy law in the past three years.

questions.question: Do you have a dedicated data privacy staff or office?
questions.standard_guidance: This can include another office, such as information security, dedicated to privacy protection.
questions.no_guidance: Describe who is responsible for data privacy, including department, size, talents, resources, etc.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe your data privacy office, including size, talents, resources, etc.
questions.reason: Any solution provider processing protected student data should have resources/staff dedicated to the protection of the data.

questions.question: If you have completed a SOC 2 audit, does it include the Privacy Trust Service Principle?
questions.standard_guidance: SOC 2 Type II audits can be conducted for any or all of five trust principles (confidentiality, integrity, availability, security, and privacy). Answer "yes" if your audit included the privacy principle.
questions.no_guidance:
If your SOC2 Type II audit does not include the Privacy Trust Service Principle, please explain why it was not included at this time, and provide any plans to include it in future SOC 2 audits. 

If the Privacy Trust Service Principle was not (or will not be) included in the SOC 2 audit, please provide an overview of any other reviews your organization conducts that might address the Privacy Trust Principles.
questions.yes_guidance: Please indicate whether your organization will allow clients to review current SOC 2 Type II reports and, if so, how the reports will be made available in a timely manner.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: This is specifically asking for the Privacy Trust Service Principle, which is not always included in a SOC 2 audit.

questions.question: Do you conform with a specific industry-standard privacy framework (e.g., NIST Privacy Framework, GDPR, ISO 27701)?
questions.standard_guidance: Standard privacy frameworks help organizations enhance data protection, mitigate privacy risks, and demonstrate compliance with appropriate industry and regulatory standards. This is particularly important when providing services in different jurisdictions.
questions.no_guidance: Please provide any plans to conform with one or more of the industry-standard frameworks, including anticipated timelines, and indicate which framework(s) will be used.
questions.yes_guidance: Indicate which framework(s) are followed; provide documentation on how your organization conforms to your chosen framework(s) and indicate current certification levels, where appropriate.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: Conformance with industry privacy frameworks can demonstrate an organization's privacy posture and can provide clients a sense of comfort as to the organization's commitment to protection of personal data.
questions.followup: If the organization relies on more than one framework or only on portions of a framework, has this been mapped to the Security Controls Framework? If so, please provide a copy of the mapping used.

questions.question: Does your employee onboarding and offboarding policy include training of employees on information security and data privacy?
questions.no_guidance:
Please provide any plans to develop and implement appropriate employee training as part of onboarding and offboarding.

If no plans currently exist, please provide information on any compensating measures your organization takes to address this issue.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide an overview of your organization's relevant onboarding/offboarding policy and employee training on information security and privacy.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: It is important that new employees be informed of organizational and individual expectations, obligations, and processes for protecting the privacy of personal data entrusted to your organization. It is equally important to ensure departing employees are informed of expectations and thier obligations to maintain protection and privacy of personal data they may have been privy to in the course of their employment with your organization.
questions.followup: If training is provided to specific employee groups only, please provide information as to which groups and an overview of the training for each group.

questions.question: Do you have contractual agreements with third parties that require them to maintain standards and to comply with all regulatory requirements?*
questions.standard_guidance: Inclusion of language in contractual agreements ensures third parties are aware of and have agreed to their obligations to maintain standards and comply with all regulatory requirements in regards to protection of personal data they handle on behalf of your organization.
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to ensure appropriate language is included in new and renewed contracts. State how your organization ensures that third parties maintain standards and comply with all regulatory requirements without contractual agreements to do so.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a summary of the contractual language used and your processes for ensuring appropriate language is regularly reviewed and is included in both new and renewed agreements.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your organization, product or service.
questions.reason: Inclusion of language in contractual agreements ensures third parties are aware of and have agreed to their obligations to maintain standards and comply with all regulatory requirements in regards to protection of personal data they handle on behalf of the organization.

questions.question: Do you perform privacy impact assesments of third parties that collect, process, or have access to personal data to ensure they meet industry and regulatory standards and to mitigate harmful, unethical, or discriminatory impacts on data subjects?
questions.standard_guidance: Privacy impact assessments ensure that third-party collection, processing, or access to personal data aligns with and supports your organization's own efforts and commitments to clients. This is particularly important when a specific third party operates from or is subject to a jurisdiction different from that of your organization.
questions.no_guidance: State your plans to perform data privacy assessments of third parties, including anticipated timelines and remediations if existing third parties cannot maintain or ensure privacy and security of client data entrusted to your organization.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a summary of your practices that assures that the third party will be subject to the appropriate standards regarding data privacy.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: The organization providing a product or service cannot reasonably claim it appropriately protects privacy of information entrusted to it if it relies on third parties or subprocessors that do not likewise meet or exceed the claimed levels of protection.
questions.followup:
If answer is "YES"...
Provide a list of third parties that were subject to a privacy impact assessment, the jurisdiction within which they operate, and the corresponding industry and regulatory standards for each.

If answer is "NO"…
If there are no plans to perform data privacy assessments of third parties, please explain any compensating measures or controls your organization relies on to ensure the privacy and security of client personal data entrusted to your organization.

questions.question: Does your change management process include privacy review and approval?
questions.standard_guidance: The change management process minimizes disruption and maximizes benefits and should contain a privacy review process.
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to implement.
questions.yes_guidance: Please describe your process for privacy review.
questions.reason: It is important that change management not overlook any privacy considerations.
questions.followup: If the answer is yes, describe the process; if the answer is no, describe plans to implement.

questions.question: Do you have policy and procedure, currently implemented, guiding how privacy risks are mitigated until they can be resolved?
questions.standard_guidance: Policy and procedure should include specific steps to take in the process of mitigating privacy risks.
questions.no_guidance: Describe any plans to implement.
questions.yes_guidance: Please provide an overview of privacy risk mitigation.
questions.reason: It is important to have a procedure in place to mitiage privacy risks as they come up.
questions.followup: If the answer is yes, describe the process; if the answer is no, describe plans to implement.

questions.question: Do you collect, process, or store demographic information?*
questions.standard_guidance: Demographic information is generally defined as the statistical characteristics of a population used to study and understand certain aspects of that population. It can include characteristics such as age, gender, ethnicity, education, religion, geolocation, and occupation. If the information being collected, processed, or stored falls under a particular regulation (or law), check that regulation for a specific definition of demographic information.
questions.no_guidance: Demographic information is generally defined as the statistical characteristics of a population used to study and understand certain aspects of that population. It can include characteristics such as age, gender, ethnicity, education, religion, geolocation, and occupation. If the information being collected, processed, or stored falls under a particular regulation (or law), check that regulation for a specific definition of demographic information.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe which demographic information you handle and the source of the requirements, if applicable.
questions.reason: This data can be included in data sets that are deidentified but is sensitive data that could be reidentified if paired with other data points.
questions.followup: Because of the nature of such data, it is important to have a full understanding of how the data is used and protected.

questions.question: Do you capture or create genetic, biometric, or behaviometric information (e.g., facial recognition or fingerprints)?*
questions.standard_guidance:
Genetic information would include information about genetic tests, genetic tests of family members, actual manifestations of diseases, and family medical records. Biometric information includes elements such as facial recognition, fingerprints, and voice recognition.
Behaviometric information is behavioral information collected and analyzed in order to understand human behavior. The exact elements collected may depend on the requirements of an applicable regulation or law.
questions.no_guidance:
Genetic information would include information about genetic tests, genetic tests of family members, actual manifestations of diseases, and family medical records. Biometric information includes elements such as facial recognition, fingerprints, and voice recognition.
Behaviometric information is behavioral information collected and analyzed in order to understand human behavior. The exact elements collected may depend on the requirements of an applicable regulation or law.
questions.yes_guidance: Briefly summarize your use of such information and the protection thereof.
questions.reason: This data can be included in data sets that are deidentified but is sensitive data that could be reidentified if paired with other data points.
questions.followup: Because of the nature of such data, it is important to have a full understanding of how the data is used and protected.

questions.question: Do you combine institutional data (including "de-identified," "anonymized," or otherwise masked data) with personal data from any other sources?*
questions.standard_guidance: Institutional data is created, collected, maintained, transmitted, or stored by or for a college or university to conduct operations. Many institutions have their own specific definitions. Institutional data would include data such as financial information, student education records, faculty/staff/alumni data, research data, and data collected for government reporting purposes.
questions.no_guidance: Institutional data is created, collected, maintained, transmitted, or stored by or for a college or university to conduct operations. Many institutions have their own specific definitions. Institutional data would include data such as financial information, student education records, faculty/staff/alumni data, research data, and data collected for government reporting purposes.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the other sources and provide a list of elements, including any keys that connect the datasets.
questions.reason: To identify potential re-identification risks and ensure the vendor doesn't merge institutional data with external datasets in ways that could compromise privacy protections or violate data use restrictions.
questions.followup: If yes, describe what types of external data sources are combined with institutional data and for what purposes.

questions.question: Is institutional data coming into or going out of the United States at any point during collection, processing, storage, or archiving?
questions.standard_guidance: Given the vast number of privacy regulations and laws throughout the world, it is important to know when, where, why, and how institutional data is being shared outside the United States. This information is necessary to ensure compliance and to protect the institutional data.
questions.no_guidance: Given the vast number of privacy regulations and laws throughout the world, it is important to know when, where, why, and how institutional data is being shared outside the United States. This information is necessary to ensure compliance and to protect the institutional data.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe where and whether you comply with the laws of that jurisdiction.
questions.reason: To assess cross-border data transfer risks and ensure compliance with international privacy regulations including GDPR, data localization requirements, and data sovereignty considerations.
questions.followup: If yes, identify which countries data flows to/from and what safeguards are in place (e.g., Standard Contractual Clauses, adequacy decisions).

questions.question: Do you capture device information (e.g., IP address, MAC address)?
questions.standard_guidance: Device information can be captured for a variety of reasons, from analytics to marketing to network management and security. It is important to know the details in order to be clear on the privacy implications.
questions.no_guidance: Device information can be captured for a variety of reasons, from analytics to marketing to network management and security. It is important to know the details in order to be clear on the privacy implications.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe what information you collect and the reason for collecting it.
questions.reason: This question can clarify whether there are any indirect identifiers that don't appear to be readily identifiable but that could be identifiable in the event of unauthorized access or use.

questions.question: Does any part of this service/project involve a web/app tracking component (e.g., use of web-tracking pixels, cookies)?
questions.standard_guidance: Web tracking can be used to identify users via their IP address, login information, browser information, etc.
questions.no_guidance: Web tracking can be used to identify users via their IP address, login information, browser information, etc.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the tracking component and what is done with the information.
questions.reason: Web tracking can be used to identify users via their IP address, login information, browser information, etc.

questions.question: Does your staff (or a third party) have access to institutional data (e.g., financial, PHI, or other sensitive information) through any means?
questions.standard_guidance: Accessing institutional data may be necessary for legitimate business purposes.
questions.no_guidance: Accessing institutional data may be necessary for legitimate business purposes.
questions.yes_guidance: Summarize the access that staff (or third parties) have to institutional data.
questions.reason: Institutional data may be sensitive in nature and should only be accessed for legitimate business purposes.

questions.question: Will you handle personal data in a manner compliant with all relevant laws, regulations, and applicable institution policies?
questions.no_guidance: If no, why not? Are there plans for this to be implemented and, if so, when?
questions.reason: Personal data that is handled improperly or against law/regulation can have significant negative impact.

questions.question: Do you have a documented privacy management process?
questions.no_guidance: Are there plans to implement? If so, when will this be completed?
questions.yes_guidance: Describe privacy management process or provide links or attach documentation.
questions.reason: It's important for customers to know their data will remain private after being shared with the vendor.
questions.followup: Are your internal privacy practices and obligations documented in internal corporate privacy policy/policies? Does the internal privacy policy explain your organization's policies and practices regarding collection of personal information and other data about individuals?

questions.question: Are privacy principles designed into the product lifecycle (i.e., privacy-by-design)?
questions.standard_guidance: The question is assessing your compliance with Privacy by Design (PbD) principles. This concept, embedded in regulations such as GDPR (Article 25) and other global privacy laws, requires that privacy is not an afterthought—it must be part of the design and architecture of systems and processes from the outset.
questions.no_guidance: State why principles are not designed into the product lifecycle.
questions.yes_guidance: Summarize the privacy principles designed into the product lifecycle.
questions.reason: Building privacy principles into the product lifecycle (e.g., privacy-by-design) can help ease the privacy management process.

questions.question: Will you comply with applicable breach notification laws?
questions.no_guidance: Provide reason for not complying.
questions.yes_guidance: State how quickly the institution will be notified once a breach is identified, in addition to notifying the necessary governmental agencies based on the extent of the breach.
questions.reason: It's very important to get out in front of the impact from a system breach. Once a breach has been confirmed, timely communication is imperative.
questions.followup: This is usually dictated by the government agency for the geographic region and, possibly, by your cybersecurity insurance carrier.

questions.question: Will you comply with the institution's policies regarding user privacy and data protection?
questions.standard_guidance: These policies may include specific user consent practices, data classification standards, and handling of sensitive information.
questions.no_guidance: Explain the legal or operational reasons and offer an alternative policy.
questions.reason: This question can help gauge a solution provider's willingness to align with institutional data privacy and protection policies before the contracting stage.
questions.followup: Do any parts of your instituitonal policy conflict with the solution provider's standard practices?

questions.question: Is your company subject to the laws and regulations of the institution's geographic region?
questions.standard_guidance: Indicates whether your organization is legally bound by state, federal, or local laws where the institution operates.
questions.no_guidance: Explain why your operations fall outside the region’s legal scope and how you nevertheless ensure regulatory compliance.
questions.reason: This question identifies whether the institution and solution provider are beholden to the same laws. If not, this should be covered in the contract.
questions.followup: Which laws apply to your operations in institution's region? Where is institutional data processed or stored? Provide a link or document summarizing your compliance stance.

questions.question: Do you have a privacy awareness/training program?*
questions.standard_guidance: Privacy awareness/training refers to the ongoing education provided to individuals who handle sensitive data to ensure they understand privacy obligations, data protection principles, and regulatory requirements (e.g., FERPA, HIPAA, GDPR).
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to include data privacy training or why you have determined it is not needed.
questions.yes_guidance: Briefly describe what is included in the training.
questions.reason: Privacy awareness/training refers to the ongoing education provided to individuals who handle sensitive data to ensure they understand privacy obligations, data protection principles, and regulatory requirements (e.g., FERPA, HIPAA, GDPR). This training helps reduce the risk of accidental data exposure and reinforces responsible data stewardship.

questions.question: Is privacy awareness training mandatory for all employees?
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to require.
questions.yes_guidance: Your response should include who must complete the training.
questions.reason: This question serves a critical purpose in evaluating a vendor or institution’s commitment to data protection, risk mitigation, and regulatory compliance.
questions.followup: This question helps assess whether privacy is treated as an organizational responsibility and whether the institution enforces consistent practices to reduce human risk factors.

questions.question: Is AI privacy and ethics awareness/training required for all employees who work with AI?
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to include AI training.
questions.yes_guidance: Briefly describe what is included in the training.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: This question is intended to assess whether an institution or vendor is proactively managing the risks, responsibilities, and ethical implications of AI use, especially as it relates to sensitive data, autonomy, and fairness.
questions.followup: This question helps assess institutional maturity in governing responsible AI use, particularly as privacy and fairness concerns rise with increased automation and data use. Clarifying the structure and enforcement of training supports transparency and accountability in AI-related operations.

questions.question: Do you have any decision-making processes that are completely automated (i.e., there is no human involvement)?
questions.standard_guidance: Examples of such automated decisions could include automatically denying or approving user access requests, flagging or blocking transactions based on risk scores, or AI-driven decisions that affect user outcomes (e.g., eligibility, grading, pricing).
questions.no_guidance: Examples of such automated decisions could include automatically denying or approving user access requests, flagging or blocking transactions based on risk scores, or AI-driven decisions that affect user outcomes (e.g., eligibility, grading, pricing).
questions.yes_guidance: Provide information on which decisions are automated and why.
questions.reason: This question identifies potential privacy, ethical, security, and compliance risks that may arise from fully automated systems, especially those that affect individuals or their data.
questions.followup: This question evaluates risk exposure and ethical considerations surrounding automated processes, especially those that affect access, compliance, or personal data rights. Transparency about the scope, oversight, and redress options for automated decision-making is critical to maintaining trust and regulatory alignment.

questions.question: Do you have a documented process for managing automated processing, including validations, monitoring, and data subject requests?
questions.no_guidance: Describe plans to implement processes in the future.
questions.yes_guidance: Briefly describe processes.
questions.reason: This question assesses the maturity of your automation governance. Documented procedures help ensure that automated systems are accountable, reliable, and capable of respecting individual rights. Lack of documentation may indicate unmanaged risks, especially in environments handling sensitive or regulated data.

questions.question: Do you have a documented policy for sharing information with law enforcement?
questions.no_guidance: Explain any plans to develop a policy. If no plans exist, explain why not.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a high-level overview of the policy or plans to implement a policy.
questions.reason: The insitution should know which laws apply to the data to which the solution provider will have access. You should also have a thorough understanding of how requests from law enforcement will be handled.

questions.question: Do you share any institutional data with law enforcement without a valid warrant or subpoena?*
questions.no_guidance: Describe how you ensure this does not occur.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the circumstances in which you share with law enforcement.
questions.reason: To protect institutional and individual privacy rights by ensuring data is only disclosed to law enforcement through proper legal channels with appropriate due process protections.
questions.followup: If yes, under what circumstances and with what documentation/notification to the institution?

questions.question: Does your incident response team include a privacy analyst/officer?
questions.standard_guidance: Provide an overview of your incident response team membership and its charge, highlighting the privacy analyst/officer.
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.yes_guidance: Provide the incident response team membership and charge.
questions.reason: Having a privacy analyst/officer on an incident response team can help the company more quickly identify a breach and comply with applicable notification laws.

questions.question: Will data be collected from or processed in or stored in the European Economic Area (EEA)?
questions.standard_guidance: See GDPR Chapter 1, Art. 4, for definitions.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe where and what activities will take place in the EEA.
questions.reason: Understanding whether the vendor processes data in Europe may help with institutional GDPR compliance.
questions.followup: If institution's intended use includes targeting of data subjects in EEA/UK and if vendor marks "no," institution might want to follow up to clarify data collected.

questions.question: Do you have a data protection officer (DPO)?
questions.standard_guidance: See GDPR Chapter 4, Section 4, for DPO information.
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.yes_guidance: Provide the name and contact information for the DPO.
questions.reason: Vendors targeting services in the EEA/UK should have GDPR-compliant policies and procedures.

questions.question: Will you sign appropriate GDPR Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) with the institution?
questions.standard_guidance: See GDPR Chapter 5, Art. 46, for SCC information.
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.reason: Vendors targeting services in the EEA/UK should have the ability to agree to the SCCs.

questions.question: Will data be collected from or processed in or stored in China?
questions.standard_guidance: See PIPL Chapter 1 for definitions.
questions.no_guidance: See PIPL Chapter 1 for definitions.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe where and what activities will take place in China.
questions.reason: Understanding whether the vendor processes data in China may help with institutional PIPL compliance.
questions.followup: If institution's intended use includes targeting of data subjects in China and if vendor marks "no," institution might want to follow up to clarify data collected.

questions.question: Do you comply with PIPL security, privacy, and data localization requirements?
questions.standard_guidance: See PIPL Chapter 5 for requirements.
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: Vendors targeting services in China should have the ability to comply with PIPL requirements.

questions.question: Have you performed a Data Privacy Impact Assesssment for the solution/project?
questions.no_guidance: Provide timeline for this or reason not to perform.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide copy, link, or summary overview.
questions.reason: To verify the vendor has systematically evaluated privacy risks and implemented appropriate safeguards before deploying their solution, demonstrating privacy-by-design principles.
questions.followup: Please provide a copy of the DPIA or summary of findings and mitigation measures.

questions.question: Do you provide an end-user privacy notice about privacy policies and procedures that identify the purpose(s) for which personal information is collected, used, retained, and disclosed?
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.yes_guidance: Provide link or copy.
questions.reason: To ensure transparency with end users about data practices and compliance with privacy notice requirements under FERPA, GDPR, CCPA, and other applicable regulations.
questions.followup: How do you inform users of changes to the policy?

questions.question: Do you describe the choices available to the individual and obtain implicit or explicit consent with respect to the collection, use, and disclosure of personal information?
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.yes_guidance: Provide copy, link, or summary overview.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 03
questions.reason: To verify meaningful consent mechanisms exist and users have adequate control over their personal information in accordance with fair information practice principles and regulatory requirements.
questions.followup: Describe your consent mechanism and how users can withdraw consent if they choose.

questions.question: Do you collect personal information only for the purpose(s) identified in the agreement with an institution or, if there is none, the purpose(s) identified in the privacy notice?
questions.standard_guidance: This includes quality assurance, marketing and advertising, etc.
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.yes_guidance: Describe purposes not included in an agreement with the institution.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 04
questions.reason: Companies may collect information for purposes not outlined in the service agreement, including quality assurance, marketing, etc. Instituions should have a thorough understanding of what data is being used and how.

questions.question: Do you have a documented list of personal data your service maintains?
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.yes_guidance: Provide copy, link, or summary overview.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 05
questions.reason: To ensure the vendor maintains data inventory records necessary for privacy compliance, breach response, data subject rights requests, and understanding the full scope of data collection.
questions.followup: Please provide your data inventory or map showing categories of personal data collected and retention periods.

questions.question: Do you retain personal information for only as long as necessary to fulfill the stated purpose(s) or as required by law or regulation and thereafter appropriately dispose of such information?
questions.no_guidance: Briefly outline data retention policies that do not align with regulations.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 06
questions.reason: Data minimization is a basic privacy principle, and it is important to know whether the solution provider is keeping data longer than necessary and introducing a significant privacy risk.

questions.question: Do you provide individuals with access to their personal information for review and update (i.e., data subject rights)?
questions.standard_guidance: Such processes would include descriptions of request processes individuals can follow to review thier information and written processes a data subject may use to ask for changes or corrections to data held about them.
questions.no_guidance: Such processes would include descriptions of request processes individuals can follow to review thier information and written processes a data subject may use to ask for changes or corrections to data held about them.
questions.yes_guidance: Such processes would include descriptions of request processes individuals can follow to review thier information and written processes a data subject may use to ask for changes or corrections to data held about them.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 07
questions.reason: This question seeks proof of an entity's ability to honor data-subject rights related to providing an individual access to their own informaiton. Such processes would include descriptions of request processes individuals can follow to review thier information and written processes a data subject may use to ask for changes or corrections to data held about them.

questions.question: Do you disclose personal information to third parties only for the purpose(s) identified in the privacy notice or with the implicit or explicit consent of the individual?
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 08
questions.reason: To limit unauthorized third-party data sharing and ensure transparency about data flows beyond the direct vendor relationship, protecting against unexpected secondary uses.
questions.followup: Provide a list of third parties who receive personal information and the purpose for each disclosure.

questions.question: Do you protect personal information against unauthorized access (both physical and logical)?
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 09
questions.reason: To verify appropriate security controls are in place to protect personal data from breaches, unauthorized disclosure, and both external and internal threats.
questions.followup: Describe your access control mechanisms, encryption methods, and incident response procedures.

questions.question: Do you maintain accurate, complete, and relevant personal information for the purposes identified in the privacy notice?
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 10
questions.reason: To ensure data quality practices that prevent privacy harms from inaccurate or outdated personal information, particularly in contexts where data accuracy affects individual rights or opportunities.
questions.followup: What processes do you have for individuals to review and correct their personal information?

questions.question: Do you have procedures to address privacy-related noncompliance complaints and disputes?
questions.yes_guidance: Provide a brief overview of processes or procedures to handle privacy-related complaints.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 11
questions.reason: To verify accountability mechanisms exist for addressing privacy concerns, providing recourse to affected individuals, and demonstrating responsiveness to privacy complaints.
questions.followup: Describe your complaint handling process, typical response times, and escalation procedures.

questions.question: Do you "anonymize," "de-identify," or otherwise mask personal data?
questions.yes_guidance: Briefly describe method used to mask data.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 12
questions.reason: To understand the vendor's approach to privacy-enhancing techniques and assess whether data masking methods are appropriate, effective, and aligned with recognized anonymization standards.
questions.followup: Describe your anonymization methodology and any validation or testing performed to ensure re-identification risks are minimized.

questions.question: Do you or your subprocessors use or disclose "anonymized," "de-identified," or otherwise masked data for any purpose other than those identified in the agreement with an institution (e.g., sharing with ad networks or data brokers, marketing, creation of profiles, analytics unrelated to services provided to institution)?
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the reason for using data beyond the agreed purpose.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 13
questions.reason: To prevent secondary use of institutional data that could undermine privacy protections, contradict institutional data governance policies, or enable commercial uses incompatible with educational purposes.
questions.followup: If yes, provide details on secondary uses and obtain specific written consent from the institution for these uses.

questions.question: Do you certify stop-processing requests, including any data that is processed by a third party on your behalf?
questions.standard_guidance: Provide evidence of existing processes or policies. The internal privacy policy should explain your organization's policies and practices regarding the collection of personal information and other data about individuals.
questions.no_guidance: Provide evidence of existing processes or policies. The internal privacy policy should explain your organization's policies and practices regarding the collection of personal information and other data about individuals.
questions.yes_guidance: Briefly outline relevant processes.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if you answered "no" to ALL of the following 7 questions: PRGN-01, 02, 03, 04 and PDAT-01, 02, 14
questions.reason: It is helpful to understand a vendor or third party's actions with data they recieve or create, which might include your organization's constituent data. Good practices include abiding by a requirement to delete or stop processing an individual's data upon request. Check your state's law to see what that requirement might be: https://iapp.org/resources/article/us-state-privacy-legislation-tracker/
questions.followup: If your organization has exchange programs or does business with global organzations or organizations located outside the United States, depending on the services sought, your institution should determine whether this is a requirement.

questions.question: Do you have a process to review code for ethical considerations?
questions.yes_guidance: Provide documentation or explanation of the process to review code. If none exists, explain why.
questions.reason: AI and other software developers increasingly ingest confidential datasets to use for output. Understanding the ethics, transparency, and other such considerations that went into the product help the purchasing organization see the position of the vendor and its etiquette toward privacy.

questions.question: Does your service use AI for the processing of institutional data?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Review the vendor’s explanation for completeness and alignment with institutional data governance policies. Follow up on vague or incomplete answers. If AI use is planned, ask them to note the expected scope.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe how your service uses AI to process institutional data. Include the types of data involved, the purpose of AI usage, and any decision-making roles AI plays.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: To identify AI-related privacy risks including potential bias, unintended disclosures, lack of explainability in automated decision-making, and training data provenance concerns.
questions.followup: Ask for documentation or a summary of how AI models are developed or used, including training data sources and whether outputs are reviewed by humans.

questions.question: Is any institutional data retained in AI processing?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Evaluate the vendor's data retention practices for compliance with institutional policies. Request clarification on retention periods and data security if needed.
questions.yes_guidance: Specify what data is retained, for how long, and how it is protected.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: This question assesses whether institutional data is stored or retained during AI processing, which may have implications for data security, retention policies, and regulatory compliance.
questions.followup: Ask for retention schedules, anonymization steps, and whether storage is temporary or permanent. Request a data flow diagram if available.

questions.question: Do you have agreements in place with third parties or subprocessors regarding the protection of customer data and use of AI?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Explain the absence of agreements and indicate whether any are under development or negotiation.
questions.yes_guidance: List all subprocessors and describe the agreements in place regarding AI and data protection.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: It's important to ensure that third-party vendors or subprocessors involved in AI processing are contractually bound to protect institutional data and comply with privacy standards.
questions.followup: Request copies or summaries of data protection agreements with subprocessors. Ask whether subprocessors are listed publicly and how they are vetted.

questions.question: Will institutional data be processed through a third party or subprocessor that also uses AI?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Confirm whether third-party AI use occurs. Ensure that oversight and contractual protections are in place. Clarify any unclear relationships.
questions.yes_guidance: Identify third-party AI processors and describe their role and safeguards.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: This question identifies whether institutional data is shared with or processed by third parties that use AI, which may introduce additional privacy or ethical considerations.
questions.followup: Ask for a list of third parties involved in AI processing and their roles. Inquire about oversight mechanisms and whether data is shared across jurisdictions.

questions.question: Is AI processing limited to fully licensed commercial enterprise AI services?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Provide names of services used and license types. Note whether open-source or experimental tools are used.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide names of services used and license types. Note whether open-source or experimental tools are used.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: In most cases, only enterprise licenses allow for an organization to customize what data is collected and how it is used. Free licenses to AI tools could introduce a risk to data.
questions.followup: Request proof of licensing or vendor agreements for AI tools. Ask whether open-source or beta tools are used and how they are evaluated for risk.

questions.question: Will institutional data be used or processed by any shared AI services?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Provide detailed response to the type of data needed for the AI service to function appropriately, the sources of the data, and whether any data shared with the AI service comes from data sources outside the institution.
questions.no_guidance: Provide detailed response to the type of data needed for the AI service to function appropriately, the sources of the data, and whether any data shared with the AI service comes from data sources outside the institution.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide detailed response to the type of data needed for the AI service to function appropriately, the sources of the data, and whether any data shared with the AI service comes from data sources outside the institution.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: Use of AI services and tools runs a risk of being supported by bad batches or databanks of information. Additionally, harmful bias and other data-quality issues can affect AI system trustworthiness, which could lead to negative impacts.

questions.question: Do you have safeguards in place to protect institutional data and data privacy from unintended AI queries or processing?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.yes_guidance: Explain any data minimization processes used to exclude institutional data from AI algorithm or training, etc.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: AI systems can present new risks to privacy by allowing inference to identify individuals or previously private information about individuals. Additionally, institutional data may be copyright protected or include other intellectual property belonging to the institution that should be protected from AI processing where necessary.

questions.question: Do you provide choice to the user to opt out of AI use?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Explain why not
questions.yes_guidance: Provide the language used for a user to opt-out or consent to the use of AI
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: To ensure user autonomy regarding AI processing of their data and compliance with emerging AI transparency requirements and ethical principles around algorithmic decision-making.
questions.followup: Describe the opt-out mechanism and any limitations or service impacts if a user opts out of AI processing.

questions.question: Does your solution leverage machine learning (ML) or do you plan to do so in the next 12 months?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Answer "yes" even if you do not create your own machine learning solutions, and answer the questions as they apply to your contractual relationship with the third party you utilize.
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the Machine Learning section (AIML)
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the Machine Learning section (AIML)

questions.question: Does your solution leverage a large language model (LLM) or do you plan to do so in the next 12 months?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Answer "yes" even if you do not train your own LLM models, and answer the questions as they apply to your contractual relationship with the third party you utilize.
questions.no_guidance: DO NOT complete the Large Language Model section (AILM)
questions.yes_guidance: DO complete the Large Language Model section (AILM)

questions.question: Does your solution have an AI risk model when developing or implementing your solution's AI model?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Examples include NIST AI RMF, OWASP Top 10, RAFT, and MITRE ATLAS.
questions.no_guidance: Describe your current AI risk management strategy. Provide a timeline for implementation of an AI risk framework, model, or methodology.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide the AI risk framework, model, or methodology used.
questions.reason: To ensure the vendor has proactive governance and has a defined, documented risk management strategy that is aligned with responsible AI.
questions.followup: Can the AI risk model or framework in use be shared? How often is it reviewed and updated? If an AI framework is not in use, what practices are currently used to address AI risks?

questions.question: Can your solution's AI features be disabled by tenant and/or user?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Provide alternate workflows to disable AI features. Describe plans to include control of AI features.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the level of AI feature control at the institutional and user level.
questions.na_guidance: N/A is only an acceptable answer if AI is the core function of your product.
questions.reason: To verify whether customers have control over AI features and can opt out when AI is not desired or creates compliance concerns.
questions.followup: How easy is it to disable/enable AI features?

questions.question: Have your staff completed responsible AI training?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Explain what alternative responsible AI awareness activities are in place, including whether future training is planned.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide the following details about your responisble AI training program: learning objectives, frequency, alignment with standards (e.g., NIST), and who is required to complete the training.
questions.reason: To confirm that staff are educated on ethical AI principles, data stewardship, bias mitigation, and compliance, ensuring responsible use and support for customers.
questions.followup: Clarify the structure and enforcement of training supports transparency and accountability in AI-related operations.

questions.question: Please describe the capabilities of your solution's AI features.
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Describe capabilities such as content (text, image, audio, speech, video, or code) generation, visual interpretation, and predictive analytics. This encompasses all AI implementations, including third-party AI geatures. Clarify use cases or limits of the model.
questions.reason: To help institutions understand the scope, functionality, and intended use cases of the AI feature(s) and evaluate whether its capabilities align with institutional needs and risk tolerance.
questions.followup: Can documentation of supported AI functions, limitations, and safeguards be provided?

questions.question: Does your solution support business rules to protect sensitive data from being ingested by the AI model?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Provide compenstating controls for data loss prevention (DLP) as it relates to the inputs and outputs of your AI features. Include a timeline for implemenitng DLP for your AI features.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide data loss prevention (DLP) features as they relate to your AI oferings. Indicate whether these DLP rules are configurable at the insitutional and/or user level.
questions.reason: To determine the risk of senstive data exposure from AI feature inputs and outputs.
questions.followup: Can you provide examples of data loss prevention (DLP) features? Where are these DLP solutions implemented? Are these DLP features customizable?

questions.question: Are your AI developer's policies, processes, procedures, and practices across the organization related to the mapping, measuring, and managing of AI risks conspicuously posted, unambiguous, and implemented effectively?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Describe the steps your developers take to manage AI risks. Include a timeline for implementing policy and procedures for managing AI specific risks.
questions.reason: To ensure that the vendor has established a mature AI governance framework, is prepared to manage the complex and evolving risks of AI, and is not likely to transfer that risk directly to customers.
questions.followup: Given that a lack of formal governance can expose our institution to significant legal and reputational risks, how can you assure us that partnering with you will not transfer these liabilities to our organization?

questions.question: Have you identified and measured AI risks?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Provide a timeline for performing an AI specific risk assessment. Describe your plan for identifying and measuring AI risk in the future.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide the standard or framework used to identify and measure AI risk.
questions.reason: To help an organization verify that the vendor has a mature, proactive risk management framework in place, which is essential to protect the organization from the legal, financial, and reputational liabilities that can arise from a poorly governed AI system.
questions.followup: Can you provide a list of moderate and high AI-specific risks? Can you explain how your company would handle the legal, reputational, and financial liabilities that our organization would face in the event your AI causes a significant incident, such as a privacy breach or an ethical failure?

questions.question: In the event of an incident, can your solution's AI features be disabled in a timely manner?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Provide a timeline for insitutions to have the capability to disable AI features in the event of an incident.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide documentation on how to disable AI features. Include a time estimate for the time between disabling the feature and when the feature is inaccessible to users.
questions.reason: The ability to disable/enable AI features is essential for containing an incident and preventing a security or ethical failure.
questions.followup: Given the critical need for a timely incident response, what is your specific, documented procedure for disabling the AI features; who is authorized to execute it; and can you provide a service level agreement (SLA) or a documented timeline for this process? Does disabling AI features require action by the vendor?

questions.question: If disabled because of an incident, can your solution's AI features be re-enabled in a timely manner?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: Provide a timeline for insitutions to have the capability to enable AI features in the event of an incident recovery.
questions.yes_guidance: Provide documentation on how to enable AI features. Include a time estimate for the time between enabling the feature and when the feature is accessible to users.
questions.na_guidance: Please explain why this does not apply to your product or service.
questions.reason: This helps an organization create a business continuity plan and incident recovery plan.

questions.question: Do you have documented technical and procedural processes to address potential negative impacts of AI as described by the AI Risk Management Framework (RMF)?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Responsible AI development per NIST AI RMF, page 25.
questions.no_guidance: Describe your plan and timeline for implementing technical and procedural processes to mitigate negative impacts of AI, as defined by the NIST AI RMF.
questions.reason: This question helps maximize the value of the AI feature(s) while minimizing the negative impacts of AI.
questions.followup: Are resources that are required to manage risks taken into account? Are mechanisms in place and applied to sustain the value of the deployed AI system? Are mechanisms in place and applied to supersede, disengage, or deactivate AI systems that demonstrate performance or outcomes inconsistent with the intended use?

questions.question: If sensitive data is introduced to your solution's AI model, can the data be removed from the AI model by request?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Please answer based on whether your AI model supports the removal or unlearning of sensitive data, whether it is introduced intentionally or unintentionally. Consider whether data can be traced and deleted from training sets, vector stores, memory, or other components of the AI system. This includes data removal in compliance with privacy regulations and customer requests.
questions.no_guidance: If data removal or unlearning is not supported, explain why and describe compensating controls (e.g., filtering, short-term memory, differential privacy). Clarify how sensitive data is managed, and note any future plans to support deletion requests.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe how the AI model supports data deletion or unlearning and whether it is manual or automated; include retention timelines, limitations, and how requests are handled. Reference compliance with FERPA, GDPR Article 17, and state privacy laws.
questions.reason: This question assesses whether the vendor can remove sensitive data from its AI model upon request. This capability is essential for privacy compliance, including GDPR (Right to Erasure), FERPA, and state data protection laws, and it helps institutions ensure that their data is not retained or used beyond its intended purpose
questions.followup: If the vendor does not support data deletion or provides an unclear response, the institution should follow up to determine how the vendor identifies, manages, and minimizes exposure of sensitive data within its AI systems. Ask for documentation or clarification on any compensating controls (e.g., data filtering, temporary memory use), data retention practices, limitations preventing deletion, and whether future support for deletion or unlearning is planned.

questions.question: Is user input data used to influence your solution's AI model?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Please answer based on whether your solution uses user input data (e.g., prompts, uploads, queries) to fine-tune, train, or otherwise influence the behavior of your AI model. Consider any use of user data for model improvement, personalization, or aggregated learning.
questions.no_guidance: Confirm that user input data is not retained or used to train the AI model. Describe controls that prevent institutional data from influencing the model, indicate whether this is included in agreements, and say how institutions will be notified and asked for consent if practices change.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe whether input data is used for personalization, training, or continuous learning. Indicate whether, if data is anonymized, institutions are notified or can opt out, and describe how use aligns with FERPA, GDPR, and state laws.
questions.reason: This question helps institutions determine whether their input data is used to train or influence the vendor’s AI model. Understanding this protects institutional data from unauthorized reuse, supports compliance with privacy and data protection laws, and ensures that any future change to data use would require institutional consent.
questions.followup: If the vendor’s response is unclear or incomplete, the institution should ask whether user input data is retained in any form (e.g., logs, embeddings, temporary memory) and how long it is stored. Confirm whether the vendor’s data sharing or processing agreement explicitly prohibits the use of institutional data for model training. If the vendor does use user input for model influence, request details on anonymization, opt-out mechanisms, and notification procedures for future changes.

questions.question: Do you provide logging for your solution's AI feature(s) that includes user, date, and action taken?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Please answer based on whether your AI features generate audit logs that record user identity, timestamp, and actions taken. Include log retention, immutability, access for administrators or auditors, and how logs support compliance and incident response.
questions.no_guidance: If audit logging is not available, explain why and describe alternate controls or planned timelines to support monitoring, incident response, and compliance.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe what audit logs capture, how long they are retained, whether they are immutable, and how they support audits and oversight.
questions.reason: This question helps institutions confirm whether AI features can be audited for user activity, data use, and system behavior. Audit logging supports regulatory compliance, incident response, and transparency in environments handling sensitive or regulated data.
questions.followup: If the vendor’s response is incomplete, the institution should confirm whether logs are segmented by AI feature, whether log data is reviewed or integrated into the vendor’s Security Operations Center processes, and how long logs are retained. Institutions should also verify whether logs are available for institutional review or external audit when required.

questions.question: Please describe how you validate user inputs.
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.standard_guidance: Please describe how your solution validates user inputs, including detection of anomalies, malicious inputs, and sensitive data. Indicate where validation occurs and how it supports security and compliance.
questions.reason: This question helps institutions assess whether the solution protects against anomalous, malicious, or sensitive inputs that could compromise AI features. Input validation supports data integrity, incident prevention, and compliance with FERPA, GDPR, and state privacy and cybersecurity laws.
questions.followup: If the vendor’s response is unclear, the institution should ask how anomalous or malicious inputs are detected, whether sensitive data is filtered, and where validation occurs (client-side, server-side, or within the AI model). Institutions may also request details on alerting, logging, and safeguards such as rate limiting or input sanitization.

questions.question: Do you plan for and mitigate supply-chain risk related to your AI features?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab
questions.no_guidance: If supply chain risk planning is not in place, explain why and note any compensating controls or future plans.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe your use of SAST, SBOM, and monitoring of third-party AI components, and how you address vulnerabilities in line with NIST and state requirements
questions.reason: This question helps institutions assess whether vendors manage supply chain risks in their AI features, which often rely on third-party models, libraries, and APIs. Institutions need assurance that vendors use practices such as SAST, SBOM, and ongoing monitoring to address vulnerabilities, while aligning with frameworks such as NIST AI RMF, NIST CSF, and Executive Order 14028.
questions.followup: If the vendor’s response is unclear, the institution should ask whether an SBOM is maintained for AI components, how often third-party models and libraries are reviewed for vulnerabilities, and whether SAST or other testing is performed. Institutions may also confirm whether the vendor’s practices align with NIST AI RMF, NIST CSF, or Executive Order 14028 requirements.

questions.question: Do you separate ML training data from your ML solution data?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab; If AIQU-01 is no, populate with B9
questions.standard_guidance: Please answer based on whether training data is kept separate from production data to protect institutional information. Include how organizational data is segregated, anonymized, or excluded from training, and state whether institutions can opt out of data use for model improvement.
questions.no_guidance: If data separation is not in place, explain why and describe compensating controls to protect institutional data from being used in training. Include whether opt-out options are available or planned.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe how training data is separated from production data, including anonymization, segregation controls, or exclusions. Indicate whether institutions can opt out of data being used in training.
questions.reason: This question helps institutions determine whether operational data provided through the solution is kept separate from machine learning training data. Without this separation, institutional data could be inadvertently incorporated into global or shared models, creating risks of data leakage, misuse, or exposure to other customers. Ensuring separation also supports compliance with privacy and security requirements under FERPA, GDPR, and state data protection laws and gives institutions control over whether their data may be used for training or model improvement.
questions.followup: If the vendor’s response is unclear, the institution should ask how data is flagged or excluded from training, whether customer data is ever used in shared/global models, and what opt-out mechanisms are available. Institutions may also request details on data environments used for training versus production.

questions.question: Do you authenticate and verify your ML model's feedback?*
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab; If AIQU-01 is no, populate with B9
questions.no_guidance: Explain why the ML model's feedback is not currently authenticated or verified.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the process used to authenticate and verify ML model feedback. Include how you detect and mitigate attempts to introduce model skewing, poisoning, or date/phrase attacks.
questions.reason: Verifying ML model feedback helps prevent skewing attacks that could distort predictions or reduce reliability.
questions.followup: Understand whether any other controls or processes are in place that would mitigate the risk of the vendor not doing the authentication or verification. How does the vendor perform trigger-sweep evaluations?

questions.question: Is your ML training data vetted, validated, and verified before training the solution's AI model?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab; If AIQU-01 is no, populate with B9
questions.no_guidance: Explain why the data is not vetted, validated, or verified. Include any future plans to implement this process, and describe any current controls that serve as substitutes for formal vetting and validation.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe how the training data is vetted, validated and verified before the AI model is trained. Include the process along with the AI/ML data policy. Discribe your validation of data labelers to validate the accuracy of the data labeling.
questions.reason: This process can reduce the risk of errors or bias, as well as poor data quality undermining the model's accuracy and integrity.
questions.followup: What other controls are in place as a substitute to this process? If not all steps are complete, what part of the process is currently being done?

questions.question: Is your ML training data monitored and audited?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab; If AIQU-01 is no, populate with B9
questions.no_guidance: Explain why training data is not currently monitored or audited, and describe any alternative safeguards in place or future plans to implement monitoring and auditing.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the current process for how training data is monitored for any anomalies and audited to detect any data tampering.
questions.reason: Training data can be targeted by attackers to influence the ML model’s behavior in harmful ways.
questions.followup: Understand whether any other controls or processes are in place that would mitigate the risk of training data being manipulated by attackers? Do you audit for trojan/backdoor patterns? How do you protect against malicious code injection when using this ML tool for coding? Are trend, alerts flag, rare-token spikes monitored?

questions.question: Have you limited access to your ML training data to only staff with an explicit business need?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab; If AIQU-01 is no, populate with B9
questions.no_guidance: Explain why access to training data is not restricted to staff with an explicit business need. Include any existing policies or controls that currently govern data access.
questions.yes_guidance: Include what roles at your organization have the ability to view or modify ML training data.
questions.reason: Training data can be targeted by attackers to influence the ML model’s behavior in harmful ways.

questions.question: Have you implemented adversarial training or other model defense mechanisms to protect your ML-related features?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab; If AIQU-01 is no, populate with B9
questions.no_guidance: Explain why training or other defensive mechanisms have not been implemented. Include controls or other policies in place that would substitute.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe the defensive strategies in place to protect ML features and how they are tested for effectiveness.
questions.reason: Adversarial training and defenses help keep models resilient against manipulation and evasion attacks.
questions.followup: What adversarial training is performed on the ML? What defense mechanisms are incorporated into the ML? How is the input validated for the ML?

questions.question: Do you make your ML model transparent through documentation and log inputs and outputs?
questions.if_then: If REQU-04 is no, populate solution provider answer with B5 in Auto Responses tab; If AIQU-01 is no, populate with B9
questions.no_guidance: Explain why the model is not documented, does not log inputs/outputs, or lacks explainability features, and describe any compensating controls or future plans to increase transparency.
questions.yes_guidance: Describe how the model is made transparent through documentation and logging of inputs and outputs. Provide explanations for predictions.
questions.reason: This process helps ensure accountability and detect misuse or anomalies.
questions.followup: How long are input/output logs retained, and how is log data protected? How often are transparency and logging processes reviewed or updated? Do logs enable post-hoc trigger correlation?

questions.question: Do you watermark your ML training data?
